panels.description: Apdex is a measure of requests that complete within a tolerable period of time for the service. Higher is better.

seriesOverrides.alias: /6h Degradation SLO \(5% of monthly error budget\).*/
/1h Outage SLO \(2% of monthly error budget\).*/

targets.legendFormat: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: monitoring Service Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_5m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"} < on(tier, type, __tenant_id__) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="monitoring"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"} < on(tier, type, __tenant_id__) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="monitoring"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_30m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"} < on(tier, type, __tenant_id__) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="monitoring"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_6h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"} < on(tier, type, __tenant_id__) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="monitoring"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

* [Stackdriver Logs: Loadbalancer Access Logs](https://console.cloud.google.com/logs/query;query=resource%2Elabels%2Eurl%5Fmap%5Fname%3D%22k8s2%2Dum%2D4zodnh0s%2Dgrafana%2Dgrafana%2Dcfagrqyu%22%0Aresource%2Etype%3D%22http%5Fload%5Fbalancer%22;timeRange=PT30M?project=gitlab-ops)
* [Stackdriver Logs: Loadbalancer Access 5xx Logs](https://console.cloud.google.com/logs/query;query=httpRequest%2Estatus%3E%3D500%0Aresource%2Elabels%2Eurl%5Fmap%5Fname%3D%22k8s2%2Dum%2D4zodnh0s%2Dgrafana%2Dgrafana%2Dcfagrqyu%22%0Aresource%2Etype%3D%22http%5Fload%5Fbalancer%22;timeRange=PT30M?project=gitlab-ops)

panels.title: rule_evaluation SLI RPS - Requests per Second

panels.content:
### Description

This SLI monitors Prometheus recording rule evaluations. Recording rule evalution failures are considered to be
service failures.

Prometheus rule groups are evaluating recording rules in a group in sequence at an interval.
If the recording of all rules in a groups exceeds the interval for the group, we could be
missing data points in the group.

If a group fails often, we should split it up or improve query performance.

To see which rules are often not meeting their target. Look at the SLI-details. The `rule_group` label will contain
information about the slow group.

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in a service fleet.
If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the fleet needs
horizontal or vertical scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: cpu component saturation: Average Service CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Disk inode utilization per device per node.

If this is too high, its possible that a directory is filling up with
files. Consider logging in an checking temp directories for large numbers
of files
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, device) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - (
        node_filesystem_files_free{fstype=~"(ext.|xfs)", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
        /
        node_filesystem_files{fstype=~"(ext.|xfs)", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: disk_inodes component saturation: Disk inode Utilization per Device per Node

panels.description:
Disk space utilization per device per node.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, device) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        1 - node_filesystem_avail_bytes{fstype=~"ext.|xfs", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"} / node_filesystem_size_bytes{fstype=~"ext.|xfs", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: disk_space component saturation: Disk Space Utilization per Device per Node

panels.description:
GCP Quota utilization / limit ratio

Saturation on a quota may cause problems with creating infrastructure resources on GCP.

To fix, we can request a quota increase for the specific resource to the GCP support team.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, project, metric, quotaregion) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        gcp_quota_usage{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      /
        gcp_quota_limit{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      ) > 0
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: gcp_quota_limit component saturation: GCP Quota utilization per environment

panels.description:
Go goroutines utilization per node.

Goroutines leaks can cause memory saturation which can cause service degradation.

A limit of 250k goroutines is very generous, so if a service exceeds this limit,
it's a sign of a leak and it should be dealt with.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
        go_goroutines{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      )
      /
      250000
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: go_goroutines component saturation: Go goroutines Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Go's memory allocation strategy can make it look like a Go process is saturating memory when measured using RSS, when in fact
the process is not at risk of memory saturation. For this reason, we measure Go processes using the `go_memstat_alloc_bytes`
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      max by (env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
        go_memstats_alloc_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      )
      /
      sum by (env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
        node_memory_MemTotal_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: go_memory component saturation: Go Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers are allocated a share of CPU. Configured using resource requests.

This is the amount of CPU that a container should always have available,
though it can briefly utilize more. However, if a lot of pods on the same
host exceed their requested CPU the container could be throttled earlier.

This monitors utilization/allocated requests over a 1 hour period, and takes
the 99th quantile of that utilization percentage in that period.
We want the worst case to be around 80%-90% utilization,
meaning we've sized the container correctly. If utilization is much higher than that
the container could already be throttled because the host is overused, if it
is much lower, then we could be underutilizing a host.

This saturation point is only used for capacity planning.
Containers that have a quota specified are excluded here and can be monitored using
the `kube_container_throttling` saturation component.
The burst utilization of a CPU is monitored and alerted upon using the
`kube_container_cpu_limit` saturation point.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    quantile by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
  0.99,
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
          rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}[1h])
        )
        unless on(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
          container_spec_cpu_quota:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
        )
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        kube_pod_container_resource_requests:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", resource="cpu", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu component saturation: Kube Container CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers can have a limit configured on how much CPU they can consume in
a burst. If we are at this limit, exceeding the allocated requested resources, we
should consider revisting the container's HPA configuration.

When a container is utilizing CPU resources up-to it's configured limit for
extended periods of time, this could cause it and other running containers to be
throttled.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}[5m])
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        container_spec_cpu_quota:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
        /
        container_spec_cpu_period:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu_limit component saturation: Kube Container CPU over-utilization

panels.description:
This uses the working set size from cAdvisor for the cgroup's memory usage. That may
not be a good measure as it includes filesystem cache pages that are not necessarily
attributable to the application inside the cgroup, and are permitted to be evicted
instead of being OOM killed.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      container_memory_working_set_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      /
      (container_spec_memory_limit_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"} > 0)
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_memory component saturation: Kube Container Memory Utilization

panels.description:
Kube container throttling

A container will be throttled if it reaches the configured cpu limit for the
horizontal pod autoscaler. Or when other containers on the node are overutilizing
the the CPU.

To get around this, consider increasing the limit for this workload, taking
into consideration the requested resources.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    quantile by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
  0.99,
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container)(
        rate(container_cpu_cfs_throttled_periods_total:labeled{container!="", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}[5m])
        /
        rate(container_cpu_cfs_periods_total:labeled{container!="", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_throttling component saturation: Kube container throttling

panels.description:
Measures Go memory usage as a percentage of container memory limit
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, cluster, pod) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      go_memstats_alloc_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      / on(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, cluster, pod) group_left()
      topk by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, cluster, pod) (1,
        container_spec_memory_limit_bytes:labeled{container=~"gitlab-pages|gitlab-workhorse|kas|registry|thanos-store",env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_go_memory component saturation: Go Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
The [Horizontal Pod Autoscaler](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/run-application/horizontal-pod-autoscale/)
automatically scales the number of Pods in a deployment based on metrics.

The Horizontal Pod Autoscaler has a configured upper maximum. When this
limit is reached, the HPA will not increase the number of pods and other
resource saturation (eg, CPU, memory) may occur.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, horizontalpodautoscaler, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_status_desired_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|urgent-authorized-projects", namespace!~"pubsubbeat"}
      /
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_max_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|urgent-authorized-projects", namespace!~"pubsubbeat"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_desired_replicas component saturation: Horizontal Pod Autoscaler Desired Replicas

panels.description:
Memory utilization per device per node.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      instance:node_memory_utilization:ratio{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"} or instance:node_memory_utilisation:ratio{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: memory component saturation: Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Netfilter connection tracking table utilization per node.

When saturated, new connection attempts (incoming SYN packets) are dropped with no reply, leaving clients to slowly retry (and typically fail again) over the next several seconds.  When packets are being dropped due to this condition, kernel will log the event as: "nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet".
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      max_over_time(node_nf_conntrack_entries{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}[1m])
      /
      node_nf_conntrack_entries_limit{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: nf_conntrack_entries component saturation: conntrack Entries per Node

panels.description:
Measures the amount of scheduler waiting time that processes are waiting
to be scheduled, according to [`CPU Scheduling Metrics`](https://www.robustperception.io/cpu-scheduling-metrics-from-the-node-exporter).

A high value indicates that a node has more processes to be run than CPU time available
to handle them, and may lead to degraded responsiveness and performance from the application.

Additionally, it may indicate that the fleet is under-provisioned.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg without (cpu) (rate(node_schedstat_waiting_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}[1h]))
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: node_schedstat_waiting component saturation: Node Scheduler Waiting Time

panels.description:
Open file descriptor utilization per instance.

Saturation on file descriptor limits may indicate a resource-descriptor leak in the application.

As a temporary fix, you may want to consider restarting the affected process.
 Lower is better.
panels.title: open_fds component saturation: Open file descriptor utilization per instance

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in a shard of a
service fleet. If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the
shard needs horizontal or vertical scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, shard) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: shard_cpu component saturation: Average CPU Utilization per Shard

panels.description:
Average CPU utilization per Node.

If average CPU is saturated, it may indicate that a fleet is in need to horizontal or vertical scaling. It may also indicate
imbalances in load in a fleet.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg without(cpu, mode) (1 - rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="monitoring"}[5m]))
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: single_node_cpu component saturation: Average CPU Utilization per Node

panels.description:
CPU utilization.

See https://cloud.google.com/monitoring/api/metrics_gcp#gcp-cloudsql for
more details.

panels.description:
Memory utilization.

See https://cloud.google.com/monitoring/api/metrics_gcp#gcp-cloudsql for
more details.

panels.description:
Data utilization in bytes.

See https://cloud.google.com/monitoring/api/metrics_gcp#gcp-cloudsql for

Delta count of number of transactions. Sampled every 60 seconds.

See https://cloud.google.com/monitoring/api/metrics_gcp#gcp-cloudsql for
more details.
